Biographical documentary.

80.author: Cecil Fernando.
notes: (Shelter ; v. 2)
(ComicsLit)

Summary: "A woman writer decides to rest inside the cabin that imparts mystically strong powers of recollection. Soon enough, those powers make her face her childhood and repressed memories. To her surprise, she is suddenly a child again with her young parents. As she relives those days, her father begins to cut a fascinatingly mysterious yet strangely threatening profile" -back cover.

122.heading: Points.
122.title: Bullet Points
122.author: J
122.appears_in: Michael Straczynski ; artist, Tommy Lee Edwards.
notes: 1 v. : col. ill. ; 26 cm.
"Contains material originally published in magazine form as Bullet Points #1-5."

"The incredible story of an alternate Marvel Universe, turned on its side after one bullet changes the entire course of history. It's World War II and America needs a super-soldier. Only one man possesses the formula to create the perfect fighting machine from volunteer Steve Rogers. But when a bullet kills Dr. Erskine along with his bodyguard, M.P. Ben Parker, Steve's destiny, and that of the Marvel Universe, is changed forever. Featuring alternate versions of the Hulk, Spider-Man, Iron Man, the Fantastic Four and more."

123.heading: Points.

124.heading: Points.
124.title: "Even I Didn't Think This Would Work!"
124.author: Dik Browne.
notes: Summary: Hagar grabs the lance of a charging knight, sticks the point in the ground, and unhorses the knight.

125.heading: Points.
125.title: "The Fatal Point"
125.author: by Andréas ; lettering by David Jackson
125.appears_in: p. 26-34 in Cheval Noir, no. 2 (Oct. 1989) ; collected in the album Fragments (New York: Nantier Beall Minoustchine, 1990).
notes: Summary: In a forest north of Wheatley-End, under the two oldest trees, known as the "Devil's Horns," a wizard named Adam Niels has built a hut. Adam has figured out how to make any sphere self-destruct by sticking a pin in a certain point on it, and has further determined that his hut is on the Earth's destruct point. Whenever he tries his procedure, spheres for miles around break in sympathy, and the villagers are sick of losing lamps. The villagers go to the hut intent on destroying it, and Adam worries what might happen. Just then a gigantic pin from outer space pokes a hole through the hut into the ground, but nothing else happens.

158.heading: Pointy Ears.
158.title: Werewolves of Montpellier
158.author: Jason.
notes: 1 v. : col. ill. ; 26 cm.
"Southern France, early 21st century. A shadowy figure sneaks across the rooftops. The fangs, the pointy ears, the fierce demeanor, the hair
is this the latest addition to the ranks of the urban werewolves so famed in movies and comic books? As it turns out, no

it's just a lonely and bored expatriate artist who spends his days bumming around his adoptive French city, and his nights dressed up as a larcenous werewolf, for kicks and thrills. But when the real werewolves of Montpellier catch wind of his impersonation, he gets a few more thrills than he bargained for on the next full moon."

176.heading: Poirier, Lawrence.
176.title: "I'm Probably Never Going to Get Married. Ever."
176.author: Lynn.
176.series: For Better or For Worse, Mar. 26, 1993
notes: Summary: Lawrence's mom has a puppy to keep her happy until Lawrence has children, and Lawrence says the puppy better live a long time.

177.heading: Poirier, Lawrence.
177.title: "I'm Sick!"
177.author: by Lynn Johnston.
177.series: For Better or For Worse, Apr. 20, 1993
notes: Summary: Mike tells Lawrence, "You're not sick," and Lawrence says he's had 11 jelly donuts and 5 coffees.

178.heading: Poirier, Lawrence.
178.title: "Is It OK If I Feel Angry For You?"
178.author: by Lynn Johnston.
178.series: For Better or For Worse, Apr. 19, 1993
notes: Summary: Mike says he's sorry Lawrence got thrown out because he's gay, and Lawrence says he doesn't want anybody feeling sorry for him.

179.heading: Poirier, Lawrence.
179.title: "Lawrence has been Acting Strangely"
179.author: Lynn.
179.series: For Better or For Worse, Apr. 17, 1993
notes: Summary: Mike finds Lawrence sitting alone at an all-night donut shop.

180.heading: Poirier, Lawrence.
180.title: "None of This is Real!"
180.author: Lynn.
180.series: For Better or For Worse, Mar. 31, 1993
notes: Summary: In disbelief on finding out that Lawrence is gay, Michael kicks a fire hydrant and punches a stop sign, injuring himself.

181.heading: Poirier, Lawrence.
181.title: "Souvenir of Ecuador"
181.author: Lynn.
notes: Summary: Mike's down because his girlfriend is in Honduras, and Lawrence says that his mom went to Ecuador for a long time, and one the souvenirs she brought back was him.

182.heading: Poirier, Lawrence.
182.title: "Talk Some Sense Into Him!"
182.author: Lynn.
182.series: For Better or For Worse, Apr. 13, 1993
notes: Summary: Lawrence tries to reason with his mom about being gay, but she won't hear it and calls his father.

186.heading: Poirier, Paul.

186.author: by P

notes: Summary: An assassin tries to kill a baby who will eventually be responsible for a nuclear war, and fails.

187.heading: Poirot, Hercule.
187.title: "Jack, der Kipper" p. 43-46 in Aus den Memoiren eines Kettensägers
187.author: Atze Atzenhofer (1987)
notes: Summary (by M. Harbeck): In a confusing crime story the chainsaw murderer fails to murder alcoholic Jack the Kipper (colloquial for drinker and allusion to Ripper) when a parody of Agatha Christie's Hercules Poirot appears and announces he will solve the crime in a presentation held in the bar's library which turns out to be a simple closed bookcase. The chainsaw murderer does not go into the cupboard and escapes the fate of being shipped in it by obscure figures to Africa. On his flight he gets caught by a family father who urges him with a gun to marry his daughter.

188.title: The Pointer Dog
notes: Dog character in the newspaper strip The Family Upstairs
